nodes.text: BinFI can efficiently identify safety-critical bits in machine learning applications affected by hardware transient faults and measure overall resilience with much lower overhead than exhaustive fault injection
Many commonly used ML computations and their compositions exhibit monotonic or approximately monotonic behavior for error propagation, enabling ordering of fault outcomes by bit significance

BinFI uses a binary-search-like fault injection algorithm that leverages (approximate) monotonicity of error propagation functions to find the SDC-boundary bit and thereby pinpoint clusters of safety-critical bits
BinFI was implemented by extending TensorFI to support DNN operators and three injection modes: binary FI, exhaustive FI, and single-bit random FI

Evaluation: BinFI was evaluated on 8 ML models (including steering models DAVE and Comma.ai, LeNet, AlexNet, VGG11, VGG16, kNN, NN) across 6 datasets (MNIST, CIFAR-10, ImageNet, German traffic signs, real driving frames, survival), using 32-bit fixed-point and varied bit widths
BinFI identified 99.56% of safety-critical bits with 99.63% precision across benchmarks (average recall and precision), significantly outperforming random FI given the same number of trials
BinFI requires about 20% of the fault injection trials of exhaustive FI (logarithmic in bit-width), corresponding to roughly 5x speedup over exhaustive FI

BinFI accurately estimates overall silent data corruption (SDC) probability: measured SDC rates deviate only slightly from exhaustive ground truth and are close across evaluated models (zero deviation for purely monotonic cases)

Random fault injection has poor coverage for identifying clustered safety-critical bits: with the same number of trials as BinFI random FI finds only about 19% of critical bits, and even exhaustive-equivalent random sampling finds less than 65%

Fault model and assumptions: single transient fault per execution in processor data path (ALUs and pipeline registers), memory/register file assumed protected by ECC/parity, faults injected at operator outputs in TensorFlow graph, only inference phase considered

BinFI is approximate and can miss a small proportion of critical bits because the EP function is often only approximately monotonic; the typical miss rate is under 0.5% and inaccuracies mainly occur for small-magnitude faults in non-monotonic intervals

Conclusion: BinFI provides an attractive tradeoff between coverage and costâ€”it locates nearly all safety-critical bits with low overhead, enabling selective protection strategies for safety-critical ML systems

Implications: results can guide low-cost selective runtime protection, vulnerability analysis against hardware fault attacks, and applicability to other safety-critical HPC ML domains (medical, scientific) where monotonic computations predominate
